bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to C. A. Weckerly, March 15, 1927

div1.p: Carter plans on sending a check to Johnson for his work on the maps for the History of Yellow Fever and wonders when Morley will supply his maps for the manuscript. She comments that her health remains poor.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to C. A. Weckerly, March 15, 1927
div1.opener:
Book
Maps
-------------
The Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public
Health,
615 North Wolfe Street,
Baltimore, Maryland.
March 15, 1927.
Dear Mr. Weckerly:
div1.p:
Your unsigned letter of March 14th. has just reached me and I
am, by this mail, sending a check for ten dollars ($10.00) to Mr.
N. B. Johnson for the preliminary work he executed on the maps I
ordered for the History of Yellow Fever. (Mem. (Dec 16/29 carbon
of letter to Mr. Johnson enclosing
check for 10.00 sent to Mr. Gillette
Rockefeller
foundation

I had hoped and expected that you would have heard from Dr.
Morley long e'er this--indeed had hoped that he had had time to fill
in (ofand have filled in) the three outline maps for which he agreed to be respon-
sible for, and had returned the maps to you to be put in permanent
shape, since the above-mentioned filling-in was simply to indicate
what was desired--the finished work to be done yourself or someone
chosen by you. I much regret this delay, but I suppose it is unavoid-
able and although I shall write to Dr. Morley on the subject within
the next few days, there is a chance, as you say, that “we may receive
little assistance from” him “before the fall.”

I have been equally unfortunate in not being able to consult with the
only man I wish to see here in Baltimore about the 4th. map (Mercator's
Mercator's
-2-
projection of the West Coast of Africa and the East Coast of
the Americas. This, on account of his having been so pressed and
harassed with other work that it was impossible for him to take on
anything else. I hope and trust, however, that we shall be able to
get together in the not far distant future, and shall, of course, notify
you as soon as this occurs.

In the meantime, let me assure you of my deep appreciation not
only of your very material assistance in my work but of your understand-
ing and kindness in these unavoidable delays.
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Mr. C: A. Weckerly,
Room 5217
Interior Building,
Washington, D. C.
P. S. As to my health, it has been bad all winter--indeed I can see
no improvement in the last twelve months. However, as long as I am
well enough to do good work on the book, its all right. The thing is
worth a lot more than I am and if I can finish it with the help of your-
self, Drs. Frost: Morley etc. I'll have justified my existence even if
I'm too “used up” thereafter to ever do anything else. I hope I won't
be, for I'm well trained along certain lines. However, this isn't the
time for me to held back for a problematic future--its the present job
that matters! Thank you[unclear] for your kind inquiry, however. Good
wishes do help--a lot!
P. S. #2: If it is perfectly convenient for you to keep the
outline maps, as heretofore, I should be grateful if you would con-
tinue to do so for the present.
L. A. C.
